title: Australia news live: independent Nicolette Boele close to victory in Bradfield; man in custody as part of Pheobe Bishop investigation
snippets:
Follow today’s news live

  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

Greens to prioritise women’s safety in next parliament

Greens leader Larissa Waters has announced the party’s priorities in the next parliament, saying she will focus on women’s safety and women’s policy across health, housing and workplace relations.

This parliament could achieve real progress: climate and environment action, dental into Medicare, free childcare, and meaningful action on the housing crisis. With the Greens being in sole balance of power, there is no excuse now for Labor to resist real reform to help people and nature.

Women’s safety and equality will be a priority of my leadership, as will acting on the climate and environment crisis plus the housing and cost of living crises people are facing.

There are three critical issues that many Tasmanians are very concerned about. I’ve been very vocal on, and there are issues that the government has consistently failed over. So, on the face of it, with the motion before us, I have no option but to support it. …

We want an accountable government that’s transparent and acts with integrity and is responsible with our resources. And certainly, that’s not what we’re getting from this government.

Continue reading...

title: Roman Massacre Debunked: New Findings Rewrite Maiden Castle’s Bloody Past
snippets: A new study reveals that the Maiden Castle burials, long thought to result from a Roman attack, were instead the product of decades of internal strife. A new study from archaeologists at Bournemouth University has revealed a surprising twist in the history of Maiden Castle, an Iron Age hillfort in Dorset. Long believed to be [...]
titles: Roman Massacre Debunked: New Findings Rewrite Maiden Castle’s Bloody Past
summary: A recent study by Bournemouth University archaeologists has overturned previous beliefs about Maiden Castle in Dorset, revealing that the Iron Age burials at the site were not the result of a Roman massacre but rather due to internal strife over several decades. This new finding rewrites the historical narrative of the hillfort's bloody past.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides a deeper understanding of Maiden Castle's history by debunking previous beliefs and providing new insights. It is useful in the sense that it corrects misconceptions, but it does not necessarily offer actionable insights or report on solutions or improvements.

title: Eating 3 Servings of Berries a Day Could Boost Healthy Aging, Study Reveals

Scientists from Edith Cowan University, Queen’s University Belfast, and the Harvard T.H. Chan School [...]
titles: Eating 3 Servings of Berries a Day Could Boost Healthy Aging, Study Reveals
summary: A long-term study conducted by scientists from Edith Cowan University, Queen’s University Belfast, and the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health has found that consuming flavonoid-rich foods such as berries, black tea, citrus fruits, and apples may reduce frailty and improve mental and physical health in older adults, potentially supporting healthier aging.
constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive because it provides actionable insights for readers on how to potentially improve their health and age more healthily. It also increases awareness about the benefits of flavonoid-rich foods and their impact on mental and physical health in older adults.

title: One in 36 Men Carry a Hidden Dementia Risk Factor, Scientists Warn
snippets: Men carrying two copies of a common genetic variant face double the risk of dementia, according to new findings from the ASPREE trial. New research has uncovered that men who carry a common genetic variant are twice as likely to develop dementia in their lifetime compared to women. The study, published in Neurology, tapped into [...]
titles: One in 36 Men Carry a Hidden Dementia Risk Factor, Scientists Warn
summary: A study from the ASPREE trial, published in Neurology, found that men with two copies of a common genetic variant have a doubled risk of developing dementia compared to those without the variant. This research highlights a significant gender difference in dementia risk, indicating that 1 in 36 men carry this hidden risk factor.
constructiveness_reason: This story is informative and increases awareness about a hidden risk factor for dementia in men. It provides a deeper understanding of the gender difference in dementia risk, which can be useful for individuals and healthcare professionals. However, it doesn't clearly report on solutions or improvements, which is why it doesn't score a full 1.0.
